baseline_groups.claim_summary: Having more permanent committee members who have cited an applicant's work increases the probability of the application being funded (above payline). The main specification (Table 5, Column 3) estimates that one additional permanent reviewer who cited the applicant raises funding probability by ~2.4 percentage points (p=0.009 on synthetic data). The paper interprets this as evidence of reviewer influence on outcomes.
baseline_groups.notes: Three columns of Table 5 with progressively more controls: no controls (col1, coef=0.022, p=0.002), total reviewer cite dummies (col2, coef=0.025, p=0.009), full controls + cite dummies (col3, coef=0.024, p=0.009). All three are positive and significant. Col3 is labeled MAIN. All use meeting FE, clustered at study-section x year. N=25,000. All results on synthetic data.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Having more permanent committee members who have cited an applicant's work increases the application's percentile review score. The main specification (Table 5, Column 6) estimates that one additional citing permanent reviewer raises the score by ~0.87 points (p=0.002 on synthetic data).
baseline_groups.notes: Three columns of Table 5 for scored applications: no controls (col4, coef=0.73, p=0.002), cite dummies (col5, coef=0.85, p=0.006), full controls (col6, coef=0.87, p=0.002). All positive and significant. N=15,049 (scored applications only). Col6 is labeled MAIN.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Having more permanent committee members who have cited an applicant's work increases the probability of the application being scored at all. This effect is weaker and not significant, consistent with the paper's claim that the influence operates primarily through the scoring stage rather than the screening stage.
baseline_groups.notes: Three columns of Table 5 for being-scored outcome: no controls (col7, coef=0.011, p=0.155), cite dummies (col8, coef=0.008, p=0.453), full controls (col9, coef=0.008, p=0.449). All positive but none significant. N=25,000. The insignificance is consistent with the paper's finding that the effect operates on scores/funding, not on whether applications get scored.

global_notes: Paper is 'Expertise vs. Bias in Evaluation: Evidence from the NIH' by Danielle Li (AER, 2017). CRITICAL CAVEAT: All results are on synthetic data generated to match the variable structure of the confidential NIH administrative data. The original data is not publicly available. Coefficients demonstrate the specification search methodology but should not be interpreted as replicating the original findings. The paper studies whether permanent NIH review committee members who have cited an applicant's work influence that applicant's funding outcomes, and whether this reflects expertise or bias. The primary treatment variable is num_prevs_cite_app (count of permanent members citing the applicant). There are 115 total specifications across 14 categories. Three specifications have NaN p-values due to degenerate clustering in very small subsamples. Spec baseline/T5_col3_MAIN is the primary specification corresponding to Table 5, Column 3 of the original paper.
